Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: The latest issue of a prominent law review journal has arrived, containing articles on developing legal theories. You want to read them.
Story: I stared at my computer screen, the spreadsheet for our project open and half-finished. As a colleague, I knew I had to finish my part by today—if I didn’t, the next person in line would be stuck, and the whole team’s timeline would unravel. My phone buzzed with a reminder: the new law review journal had just arrived in my inbox. As a judge, I was expected to stay current, to read these articles and understand the latest shifts in legal thinking. I could almost hear my colleagues’ voices, counting on me to deliver, and at the same time, I felt the weight of my judicial responsibility pressing on my conscience. If I ignored the journal, I risked falling behind in my legal knowledge. If I put off the spreadsheet, I’d let my team down. My mind raced, torn between the urgent demands of my colleagues and the unyielding expectations of my role as a judge. I sat frozen, unable to choose which responsibility to honor first.
